reviewText: Loving it at about 5 hours. I actually shed tears at one part. Aside from Walking Dead, probably the most emotional game I've played yet and it's working. I have hope for smaller studios and mid level games again. AAA will continue to try to gather the widest audience, but maybe we'll get a Speilberg of games one day that'll give us a AAA like this. I don't even necessarily think it'd have to be 3D, it could still be 2D, maybe even still pixel art, but it would at least have to support widescreen and proper scaling. Maybe UbiArt. Might end up being my game of the year and that's weird. Might be my game of the year if I played it last year. Yep, enjoying it more than Black Flag or any game I can remember from the previous year.

reviewText: Always Sometimes Monsters is a hard game to review. The idea is great, presenting a gritty view of the ups and downs of life, but the lack of direction and attempts to read a deeper meaning into everything started to feel a bit long winded after a while. Every choice is yours, and you don't even need to make choices if you don't want to. You can just watch the timer tick down and stare at your character say they're hungry (but forgets about it after day 7).\nThere are no real consquences to anything you do, bad choices are there just to make you feel bad, but you easily rationalize your choices to any NPC in the game, and they just sort of shrug it off. At times I felt completely alienated from my character, simply due to their dialogue. You moved 20 boxes, got $150 and feel like you're being punished? Just a little entitled and spoiled, my pixelated friend.\nThat said, I liked it. It's too interesting not to like, but it felt like some aspects could have been polished off a little better, especially near the end where it feels rushed. If you want a reflective game, with a tongue in cheek look at reality, this is the game for you and it's a good buy for it's price.

reviewText:
This is a very good game, in my opinion.

Pros:
-A very compelling story with rather unique gameplay.
-The choices that you make clearly have an impact on how your game ends.
-Often you are forced to make morally ambiguous decisions.
-A well polished game, I could tell that everything in the game was put there for a reason.
-Thought provoking.

Cons:
-Boring and occasionally difficult minigames that need to be played in order to advance the story.
-My charachter was expected to feel guilty for actions that I thought were morally justified.
-For most of the end of the game, I kept thinking about how I could have avoided the whole conflict if I was able to play as my charachter prior to the start of the game.

It's certainly not a perfect game (as if any game could be) but, despite it's flaws, I was compelled to not only finish the game but to explore how the ending would have changed if I had chosen certain things differently. I would dare say that this is one of the best story driven games that I've played.

reviewerDisplayName: I LOVE YOU　が聞きたくて
reviewText:
I picked up Always Sometimes Monsters (ASM) through the recent Humble Bundle for $1 (Had three free copies of Insurgency, so why not?). I went into the game expecting very little from it and to uninstall it after 30 minutes, but I couldn't stay away from it.

I can see why, from the screenshots and all, a typical gamer wouldn't play this game :
-Pixel graphics (hit-and-miss)
-Really slow paced and to be honest, unecessarily draggy kind of gameplay
-Somewhat boring introduction to the narrative. (One wouldn't stay very long for this game, I would imagine)

I wasn't blown away by the game in the first hour of playing it, but it kept me playing. And why? I simply just wanted to find out where this journey would lead me, and not so much whether or not I would be able to achieve my goal.
The goal of the protagonist is essentially, getting the love of his life back. who was about to get married. Knowing that this goal was unreachable, I still just wanted to know how the story unfolds. Why? Because the protagonist was in a pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ situation and I wanted to see if it gets any better.

Apparently not. Everything just turns to ♥♥♥♥.

I was extremely disappointed at the story, and at myself. To be honest, due to its draggy gameplay, I took most of the 'shortcuts' (do one thing that I knew had a bad outcome as compared to doing three things which took more time but was more morally sound) but still stuck pretty true to what I'd do, and did some others that were morally sound to balance things out. It's interesting how these things strike back at you towards the ending and make you feel that your miserable and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ end is somewhat justifiable, and that's what's so f**ked up about it.

It is such a sad game. Don't expect fun, don't expect happiness, expect a hell of a guilt trip. It's more than a sad ending, it's a miserable one, which isn't very common in games nowadays, and is a good change of pace, but this might be way too much for one to handle. The plot twists (somewhat?) are EXTREME but yet predictable, as they're quite hard to believe.

I will not play this game again, but I will suggest this game to people.
Have a sad day.

reviewText:
Always Sometimes Monsters is a RPG where you play as a guy or gal that you choose at the beginning of the game who is trying to stop his or her true love marrying someone else.

This game is pretty damn good. At the beginning of the game you can choose which character to play as and who is your love interest. Every combination you make leads to a different outcome in some parts of the game: there is racism against interracial or homosexual couples,people interact differently, etc. The bad aspect is that these changes from playthrough to playthrough aren't as big as one might expect. Nonetheless, there are many choices throught the game that can lead to different paths.

The gameplay is similar to real life: you can do some small jobs to gain money, you have to eat regularly, you can pawn objects, go to the movies, play at the arcade and so on. It is a risky move and I understand why some people don't like it. However, I found it very fresh and interesting.

The original score by Laser Destroyer Team is really good and worth buying.

Overall, Always Sometimes Monsters is a solid RPG. The different choices and characters to choose from give the game high replayability, also thanks to its humor and soundtrack.

SCORE: 85/100

reviewText: This game was recommended to me by PC Gamer magazine. I am an older game who started gaming in the late 80s with an Atari 2600 and spent most of my gaming years in the 90s. I played on the NES, Sega Genesis, and SNES, all the way up until my parents bought me a Nintendo 64. I also played PC games. Then, I quit my gaming for a while and went to college, focusing my attention entirely on my studies. When I returned to see what the world of gaming had to offer, I was largely disappointed. The entire world seemed mostly composed of boring graphic novels and first-person shooters....That is.... until I met this game. It was like fate.\n\nI can now credit Devolver Digital with returning me back to the world of gaming. At first, I thought it was hopeless out there, but now I see that there are different niche genres out there that will even appeal to people like me. With Always Sometimes Monsters"
date: they hit the nail on the head.\n\nIf you grew up with RPG games like Shining Force

reviewText: An interesting, story rich, thought provoking indie game. You'll find that you will either reap the rewards or deal with the consequences of your decisions throughout this game, whether morally or financially. However it's unique story does not make up for it's lack of gameplay that at times makes your playthrough feel more like a chore than a source of enjoyment. Always Someties Monsters holds your interest and attention with tough decision making interactions that will ultimately shape your journey. The game does not scold or praise you for the choices you make but oddly finds a way to influence your emotions as your story unravels. Overall, a fun and unique play despite the fact that player freedom is really the only thing that holds this game together.

reviewText:
The premise and work put into making this game cater to adult themes and things that have never been in a game before is awesome.  I love what the developers did in this respect.

In the end though the gameplay was too monotonous for me to play this to completion.  I enjoyed the interactions and choices but the monotony of forced days before another instance and well the drudgery of working at menial jobs really soured the excitement I had for the game.  I mean I work at menial jobs in real life.

In the end I have other games in my library that warrant play time over this.  I do however hope the developers continue to produce games and attempt to push the boundries about gaming subject matter.  Glad I purchased it and helped the developers but in the end I cannot recommend this if you hope for a complete experience.

reviewText: This game is deep. There is no other word for it. I'll agree that if you're the type of gamer that likes action, suspense, or instant gratification, then it probably isn't for you. If you like a game with a great story, and a lot of choices, then this may be a game for you. It takes a very particular type of gamer to enjoy this kind of game. This game is about life, the pursuit of lost love. It places you in a very real role, and makes you choose your path. How much are you willing to sacrifice, how low will you sink to chase love? It's all up to you. Who your character is changes how people react to you, so it's fun to play a character that isn't like you. Try being straight, gay, white, black, asian, whatever, and you get a different perspective. You may just learn something. The soundtrack is also amazing, there wasn't a single moment in this game that I didn't enjoy listening to.

reviewText:
If this had been an adventure game it would have been a lot better. As it is, the JRPG format makes the game quite tedious.


The biggest problems are the mini-games and the lack of quest markers.


The mini games just break the pacing of the story line. One example is a storyline where you have to hack the electoral system to rig an election. To me, the important thing is whether you decide to rig the election, and which candidate to favour; rather than interrupting it with Frogger-TRON.


The lack of clear quest markers is a problem because this is a top-down RPG. Think of an old style adventure game where you would scan the screen with your mouse cursor to find the interactive elements. Here, you have to walk your character around the area and try interacting with all the surfaces to find the one that triggers the next phase of the quest". One example is when you're told to start boxing. You would think you'd go to the boxing ring
date: nope. How about those two guys training with the hook and jab pads
recommended: nope. The guy training at the punch bag
hoursPlayed: nope. Turns out you have to go to the guy lifting weights in the corner to start boxing. I'm not asking to be led by the nose to the next quest trigger
voteText: but some of the trigger points are counter-intuitive and/or downright obtuse. The game is about making decisions
helpfulPercent:
and this element of find-the-thing/trigger just breaks the pacing of the story.


I didn't finish the game

reviewText: This ia a beautiful game. As of writing this now, I've only clocked in about 5 or 6 hours. I lost track lol. It's a wonderful game with a captivating story. Unlike other games, Always Sometimes Monsters makes the player actually feel like they are in the game. You're constantly brought up with the theme of choice.  Every little thing is a choice. You're not forced to do whatever it is that you're doing.  If you don't want to let the man in the first minute speak, you can kill him and be done. If you are interested in his story, you can let him speak.   No matter what you do, it's all about choice, and that's what I enjoy about this game.\n\nLet's not forget about the music and art style. Even though the game is comprised of sprites, it's still great. The music is just amazing. It fits the story perfectly. It's like a typhoon of beauty.  For anyone who is looking for a game with an amazing story, something to open your mind, or just to feel true freedom in how you play something, this is a game to look for.  This is a must play for everyone.

reviewText:
Always Sometimes Monsters is a creative RPG that was created by Vagabond Dog and published by Devolver Digital. It is available on Steam for the low price of $10. In Always Sometimes Monsters, you have just lost the love of your life and you have not payed the rent of the month to the landlord. The landlord takes your keys, leaving you homeless when you receieve an invitation that the love of your life is marrying another man. You decide to go and interfere, causing a series of events to occur as you try to get to the wedding by the end of the month.
Story - For the ten minutes I was very confused. Then, the story began to unfold letting me know I had to get to this girl in x amount of days or else it's all over. I have actually never seen this type of story in a game, so I definitely found it quite interesting to go through. There were surprises at every turn that allowed the game to go into more depth and the story is definitely worth an honorable mention.
Graphics  - As mentioned above, this is an RPG game, a 2D one at that. This game was created on the RPG Maker, but it excels in what the engine gives it with some very smooth looking character models and creative art for the buildings. Saying that, the graphical art is definitely not spectacular, but it definitely fits with the RPG style of the whole game, which is more than many developers can say.
Controls - The controls do take some getting used to, but they are definitely not clunky". The controls definitely could have been better
date: but they work and they work with little to no response time.\nFun Factor - I was very eager to play on the game
recommended: actually staying up later in the night than any other game that has released this year
hoursPlayed: which definitely means something. The replayablity of this game is very high as you can pick different decisions and some have a big difference in the game
voteText: which is one of the things I enjoy the most about this game.\nRecap Negatives - The controls could have been better
helpfulPercent: but were overall good. The graphics are nothing special
votesHelpful: yet it is an RPG
votesTotal: so take that into consideration.\nFinal Score:  9/10"

reviewText: (Note: I have not completed this game. I do not plan on coming back to it.)\n\nDespite its desperate pleas to be the Indie Game of the Now, Always Sometimes Monsters is a pretentious, sloppily-written slog of a game that deserves neither your time nor your money. Its two developers are far too comfortable hiding behind its laughable mission statement to bother crafting a believable world for its cast of shriveled archetypes to inhabit, and this oversight stops any momentum that its mildly interesting premise may have afforded. If video games are going to be taken seriously as a narrative form, at some point we're going to have to admit that merely donning the airs and vestments of intellectualism without actually saying anything of importance isn't enough to warrant critical attention. The only themes I got out of three hours of Always Sometimes Monsters were choice matters
recommended: and you're responsible for your actions."  If this truly deserves the bevy of positive "thinking man's" reviews that this title has received
hoursPlayed: maybe I'm in the wrong line of work.\n\n4/10"

reviewText:
It seems really great in the beginning but ends up disappointing in the end.

The further you get into the game, the more depressing things you witness and are forced to do along with heavy repetition on your chosen jobs which are just boring repetitive tasks.

Its pretty fun that you get to choose the main character and then your love interest but then the fun ends and you are warped into a game about making you feel like junk. Every moment you play its just about you either being a horrible person or others around you being scum of the earth. They throw you with all these political kinda views and horrors of society but not in a fun kinda way. More like a rapid slap to the face with no alternative solutions. You either take path A or path B....and both make you kinda feel guilty in the end.

I managed to get through the whole thing to the end and....I can't really say the ending was a payoff at all.




SPOILERS:

Your choice is to let your romance be with their new lover and you end up on the streets as a failure....but if you take your romance back, their lover will end up on the streets as a failure. None of these options are enjoyable at all. Sure the first is the proper happy ending, but how can that be when your best friend has ended up on the streets as a vagabond to be gunned down.

Everyone is bitter. Everyone is whiny. And everyone is a backstabber in this game. Heck, you are even forced to be one yourself. By the end of it, I felt kinda crummy.

In all, I think its more of an ARTSY kinda game so people who like that kinda stuff will probably get a kick outta it. For me? It really has no re-play value and I didn't care for it.

reviewText:
I honestly would not recommend this game. Also note that I was actually excited for this game before it was released. I'm going to do my best to avoid all spoilers.

I love indie games, I'm a fan of retro graphics. I'm a huge fan of storytelling type games even if it has minimal gameplay.

But this game has a very weak narrative that just doesn't make sense if you try to analyze any of it past the base level. All the 'twists' don't make sense. It feels forced and contrived at points.

Also the moral choices feel about as subtle as a bat to the face over and over again. Most of the choices were extremely obvious, back away from this situation or somebody dies.  But the 'moral choice' was always much longer in terms of gameplay time which meant more boring 'minigames' and by the time I was halfway through I just wanted the game to end to see how the story finished.

Also quite a few of the moral choices weren't obvious in terms of the game forcing you into the situation first and then asking you to reconsider. I'm already there man, and there was no dialogue to just say no from the start so might as well see how this plays out.

I got pretty tired of half the music looping after about 15-30 seconds.

It felt like any message they were trying to deliver was basically drowned out by all the archetypical stereotypical characters they presented in the game. Yes, they weren't trying to say 'all drugs are bad mmkay' but it felt that way. Yes, they weren't trying to say 'religion will set you free!' but it felt that way. The writing didn't express the author's intent as much as it did the characters moral values which were always extremely black and white. The authors definitely wanted a grey moral area but I felt it lacked the execution to do so.

Ah well, I feel like the dev could make a promising sequel/game from what they've learned after making this game.

reviewText:
Always Sometimes Monsters was a nice game about being homeless and scrounging up money to get to your ex's wedding, that I received as a gift.

The game starts off at a party, you are Larry. You go around talking to your guests, which all offer a drink. Whoever you pick then becomes your character for the rest of the game as you decide their names by what you write on his birthday card.  It's a more interesting than the usual selection menu and while it may feel like a small detail, I really liked how this was handled.

I very much enjoyed this game but I'm going to come across as negative review - the game is made on the RPG Maker engine, which I have used but don't particularly like. You press space-bar to progress dialogue but also choose your decision so if you're reading quickly you might occasionally select the wrong thing if you don't expect a dialogue box to show up or talk to a character again once they've finished speaking. They aren't bad but I'm not a particular fan of the engine's graphics either - individual environment sprites look very nice and the title screen is gorgeous but you can always tell that RPGMaker uses a square tile-based grid because grass instantly turns into a pavement with no overlays or curves. These are all personal grudges however and ones I'd apply to more games than just this one.

The writing isn't perfect - None of the characters converse like real people, but this is a video game so I can forgive it and the overall plot was interesting enough that while I noticed it frequently, I wasn't particularly bothered by it. I actually felt kinda bad for my character, although some of the choices made would definitely make them unsympathetic. A lot of the decisions are fairly big and really interesting - there's one right at the end that I loved and seriously struggled with.

Always Sometimes Monsters is set over a course of 30 in-game days, doing certain tasks will move time forward and at the end, you need to sleep. I enjoy games that use time as a mechanic and there was a genuine thought of '♥♥♥♥ I need to get moving, I might actually miss this wedding' while playing, so I feel it's done well.  The idea is that each day brings different tasks, certain shops are only open at x times and it's appreciated, because it gives you a direction to go in.

The initial task is to get money so you can pay your apartment rent and get the key back. When the game has things going for it, choices to make and new things occurring, it's a lot of fun to see you're taking the story and I seriously got into it. The game doesn't have enough plots/choices for all 30 days so sometimes, while it starts off very strongly, the flow can get broken and you'll wake up from your bed wondering if there's something I'm missing somewhere or if I should just spent the day making money.  For example, a certain character offered to give me a lift, which was great, they said they'd contact me in a few days which I then spent killing time because there didn't seem to be any objectives left.

On a different engine with more experienced writers, this game has a potential to be a lot better, which isn't to say it's bad. I stuck with Always Sometimes Monsters to the end and I'm glad I did - the ending was good and the journey was worth sticking with. It deserves praise for trying new things and bringing fresh ideas, not all of which work, but it gets points for trying.

reviewText:
So, right out of the gate -- no doubt, this game is sort of a hot mess.

There's typographical errors. (Of course, like the game points out, there's got to be at least a million words in this thing, so, the fact that less than a dozen got spelled wrong is not damnable.)

Upsetting, plot-damaging bugs abound.  Nothing game breaking, but some sources of confusion and dismay.  (A testimony, perhaps, to the power of the game, which drives one to complete tasks, to witness the consequences of one's actions and really experience the result of their action.)

As some have noted, the tone of the writing (dialogue, in particular) is occasionally sophomoric.  A fine description of it likened it to Kevin Smith - to which I would only add that while it bears a resemblance to Smith's fascination with blending the scatological and the emotional, the humane and the profane -- it also has a feel distinctly like Richard Linklater's existential slacker philosopher-poets.

And yes, it offers a staggering array of choice in everything other than the main plot, which occasionally railroads you sharply and channels you in one, inexorable direction.  (One might note that the game never claimed to be a sandbox, and offers rather more narrative selection than any other RPG I'm aware of.)

All that said, fresh from my second playthrough -- hot damn, if you can get past that, you're in for a real treat.  This is a complicated little machine, and the charm of it isn't in the polish, but in the fact that it is something new and fresh and original and kind of brilliant.  It is some supercharged mutant unleashed on the indie gaming public, and for people who can pick up it's wavelength, it's possibly going to spoil mainstream twitch-reflex gaming for you forever.

There are some real feels that can be had playing through this thing if you give in to the immersion -- heightened, rather than than in spite of, the occasionally cumbersome interface.  Some of the mini-games had me holding my breath, or tense, concerned about the consequences.  Some of the more emotional moments evoked a powerful, visceral reaction.  One noteable moment of horrific violence involving a poorly secured satellite dish made me laugh out loud, torn between horror at what I had so casually done, delight at the response from the NPCs, and shock at this unexpected shift in tone and action.  And while the dialogue is occasionally a little clunky, the underlying narrative structure and overall outlook of the game was done by someone with a fine capacity for empathy and a more than uncommon understanding of the human condition.

If anyone out there still has doubts about a videogame's capacity to be a storytelling medium or a work of art, point them at Always Sometimes Monsters, which in uniqueness and singularity of vision is surpassed, possibly, only by - maybe - a work of artisinal obsession like Dwarf Fortress.

For you fans of post-modernism -- you are in for a treat and then some.

Even if this game, in play, was a disaster, I would have given it a postive review for it's ambition and it's outlook.  A relief, then, to be able to endorse it even more full throttle than that -- this game is really playable, and despite a little bit of 'ugh, I have to play THIS level again?' lends itself well to more than one replay.  I'll probably let it cool down for a week or three, but I can see myself returning to it soon.

I simply can't say enough good things about this game.  Thanks, Vagabond Dog, for an awesome experience.

reviewText:
Coming from a background of someone that loves sim games, I honestly didn't know what to expect with Always Sometimes Monsters. In the beginning of the game, it felt really weird and I felt as though the game didn't know which genre it wanted to be. After getting past the introduction; however, that is where the real drama happens and I was pleasantly surprised by how great the quality of the narrative is.

Basically, you are trying to get to the wedding of your ex in the next 30 days, but you are broke and have no family or any other means to help you get to where you need to go. Fufilling jobs, getting favors, and doing side missions, all the while keeping your stamina needs up are key to winning the game. There's also a choice system as well, and depending on your actions, you can change the ending of the game.

Honestly, Always Sometimes Monsters felt as though I was binging a Netflix series. The game is just beautiful in terms of how immersive the storyline can be. I made myself the main character and my partner as the ex and things got real pretty quickly!

Also, I have to give the creators a round of applause for allowing not only interracial relationships but also same sex relationships as well.

Pros:
+Excellent narrative with real customization options to make the story your own.
+Game play that really keeps you on edge, clock ticking anxiety makes it exhilarating.
+Mini-games are really fun and quite symbolic to life as well.
+The soundtrack is really good! Very memorable soundtrack.

Cons:
- The choice sections come up really fast. I wish there was a delay or something before the choices come up, because there has been numerous occasions where I would hit the space bar to progress dialogue and accidentally make a choice that I didn't want to make!!! Please somehow fix that!

Overall, I would most definitely reccomend Always Sometimes Monsters. I just finished the game and I'm still emotional at the ending I got. Definitely worth the time and money. It's like reading an interactive book. Highly, highly recommended!

reviewText:
After some 10 hours I beat Always sometimes monsters. It was definitely one of the more interesting games I've played but, ultimately, I felt its own gaminess was its downfall.

The story pushes you thru a number of challenges, like getting evicted or needing to get to another city. I tried to play it realistically, putting myself in the shoes of the characters, but the suspension of disbelief was quickly broken by ridiculous video game quest trope. Cue having to win 4 boxing matches to get new tires for a car or casually hacking into a government computer to rig elections. The occasional horrible minigames are more of an annoying hindrance than a fitting part of the story.

For a game that focuses on choice, it gives you none as far as the main goal goes. You spend 30 days trying to get to a wedding of an ex-girlfriend because... plot? It's never really explained until the end and the few flashbacks don't do much to make you want to win your old love back. It's even more awkward when several times the NPCs ask you why you are going through all this trouble to get there. Frankly... I had no idea. Because that's what the game tells me to do?

I was also a bit disappointed with how the game evaluates all your choices. Towards the end, a character calls you out on all your evil deeds" which kinda made me scratch my head. So I am a horrible person because I didnt smash a doctor's car to help a junkie "friend" I only met through a few skimpy lines of dialogue? Really? And the very final flash-forward scene literally depicted me as homeless and asking to be killed because I've become a monster... wtf? I've never harmed anyone

reviewText:
Always Sometimes Monsters was a nice game about being homeless and scrounging up money to get to your ex's wedding, that I received as a gift.

The game starts off at a party, you are Larry. You go around talking to your guests, which all offer a drink. Whoever you pick then becomes your character for the rest of the game as you decide their names by what you write on his birthday card.  It's a more interesting than the usual selection menu and while it may feel like a small detail, I really liked how this was handled.

I very much enjoyed this game but I'm going to come across as negative review - the game is made on the RPG Maker engine, which I have used but don't particularly like. You press space-bar to progress dialogue but also choose your decision so if you're reading quickly you might occasionally select the wrong thing if you don't expect a dialogue box to show up or talk to a character again once they've finished speaking. They aren't bad but I'm not a particular fan of the engine's graphics either - individual environment sprites look very nice and the title screen is gorgeous but you can always tell that RPGMaker uses a square tile-based grid because grass instantly turns into a pavement with no overlays or curves. These are all personal grudges however and ones I'd apply to more games than just this one.

The writing isn't perfect - None of the characters converse like real people, but this is a video game so I can forgive it and the overall plot was interesting enough that while I noticed it frequently, I wasn't particularly bothered by it. I actually felt kinda bad for my character, although some of the choices made would definitely make them unsympathetic. A lot of the decisions are fairly big and really interesting - there's one right at the end that I loved and seriously struggled with.

Always Sometimes Monsters is set over a course of 30 in-game days, doing certain tasks will move time forward and at the end, you need to sleep. I enjoy games that use time as a mechanic and there was a genuine thought of '♥♥♥♥ I need to get moving, I might actually miss this wedding' while playing, so I feel it's done well.  The idea is that each day brings different tasks, certain shops are only open at x times and it's appreciated, because it gives you a direction to go in.

The initial task is to get money so you can pay your apartment rent and get the key back. When the game has things going for it, choices to make and new things occurring, it's a lot of fun to see you're taking the story and I seriously got into it. The game doesn't have enough plots/choices for all 30 days so sometimes, while it starts off very strongly, the flow can get broken and you'll wake up from your bed wondering if there's something I'm missing somewhere or if I should just spent the day making money.  For example, a certain character offered to give me a lift, which was great, they said they'd contact me in a few days which I then spent killing time because there didn't seem to be any objectives left.

On a different engine with more experienced writers, this game has a potential to be a lot better, which isn't to say it's bad. I stuck with Always Sometimes Monsters to the end and I'm glad I did - the ending was good and the journey was worth sticking with. It deserves praise for trying new things and bringing fresh ideas, not all of which work, but it gets points for trying.

reviewText: This game broke my heart into tiny pieces and im feeling kinda depressed right know. In fact it is a painful game that gives you ultimate life lesson. A piece of work!﻿ I recommend it for everyone who wants a  a deep emotional and dark story where you have many different choices and endings. Do you want to be a good or a bad person? A good or a bad friend? Do you want to save a life of a person or let him die? For some of these i literally had to stop for a bit of time  to think about it and these decisions are really hard to make, like life is generally. And of course the game is also full of humour: Want to sell drugs or work in a weed farm? Want to meet the developers in this game ( meta duuuuuddeeee)? Or do you want to invest in sandwich shares? You can also put hundreds of packages into a van until you realise at the end that all this time was lost for nothing (srsly dont, just dont do it, i raged so hard). And if this didnt convince you, you can also masturbate under the shower and poop in the toilet :D Nahhhh but seriously this game is awesome, you need to buy it to understand what im talking about. Choice is an evaluation of cost and benefit. Circumstance dictates the evaluation. The choice to buy this was the right one to make.

reviewText:
I had a feeling that I would enjoy this game and was really excited when I started following it through its development.

I was not disappointed in the least. Despite the fact that there was zero combat, it still kept me quite engaged - mainly because I was invested in the narrative.

There were small things I could nitpick about it, like the mini-games you use the gain money are quite mind-numbing. However, that's pretty much all meaning jobs. So I understood what they were trying to capture there, but it was a tad too on the nose.

At the end of the game, your choices are reflected very well in my opinion. There were some complaints about you, as the player, making the choice of others, but I was a little more forgiving of that. Needless to say, my ending was rather dark. It made me very sad because I've had to make those choices in my personal life and could relate to how brutal that can be.

If you are interested in games with a decent narrative and don't mind the mini-games, I would highly suggest giving it a shot. It's not often a game makes you sit down and reflect on your own choices. A game that has the ability to do that has my recommendation.

reviewText: This game broke my heart into tiny pieces and im feeling kinda depressed right know. In fact it is a painful game that gives you ultimate life lesson. A piece of work!﻿ I recommend it for everyone who wants a  a deep emotional and dark story where you have many different choices and endings. Do you want to be a good or a bad person? A good or a bad friend? Do you want to save a life of a person or let him die? For some of these i literally had to stop for a bit of time  to think about it and these decisions are really hard to make, like life is generally. And of course the game is also full of humour: Want to sell drugs or work in a weed farm? Want to meet the developers in this game ( meta duuuuuddeeee)? Or do you want to invest in sandwich shares? You can also put hundreds of packages into a van until you realise at the end that all this time was lost for nothing (srsly dont, just dont do it, i raged so hard). And if this didnt convince you, you can also masturbate under the shower and poop in the toilet :D Nahhhh but seriously this game is awesome, you need to buy it to understand what im talking about. Choice is an evaluation of cost and benefit. Circumstance dictates the evaluation. The choice to buy this was the right one to make.

reviewText:
I had a feeling that I would enjoy this game and was really excited when I started following it through its development.

I was not disappointed in the least. Despite the fact that there was zero combat, it still kept me quite engaged - mainly because I was invested in the narrative.

There were small things I could nitpick about it, like the mini-games you use the gain money are quite mind-numbing. However, that's pretty much all meaning jobs. So I understood what they were trying to capture there, but it was a tad too on the nose.

At the end of the game, your choices are reflected very well in my opinion. There were some complaints about you, as the player, making the choice of others, but I was a little more forgiving of that. Needless to say, my ending was rather dark. It made me very sad because I've had to make those choices in my personal life and could relate to how brutal that can be.

If you are interested in games with a decent narrative and don't mind the mini-games, I would highly suggest giving it a shot. It's not often a game makes you sit down and reflect on your own choices. A game that has the ability to do that has my recommendation.

reviewText: I recommend this game.  It's ... an 'experience'.  I can't say it falls into any usual" categories.  It's definitely about choices and consequences.  Stellar story
date:
whichever way you lead it.  Has a philosophical punch to it.  Good doses of humour.  Lots of 'Easter Eggs'.  Some humourous references that only Canadians will get :D

You can really do anything in this game.  You'll work at some very different jobs.  You'll pawn stuff.  You'll invest.  You'll steal and blackmail.  You'll fish.  You'll race cars.  You'll play casino games.  You'll masturbate in the shower....  that was a nice touch actually  :D

The best I can really say is it's an experience.  It's an experience whatever price they are asking... I don't think it's that much.  Get it.  Play it.  Smile and search your soul."

reviewText: I am absolutley in love with this game, this is truly a game of moral choice and all the grey areas in between. You often finding yourself weighing whats right versus what will make you happy, and even then theres no promises it'll work out.\nThe game is surprisingly fun and addicting considering most of the game has you collecting money to pay your rent or buy a bus ticket, and watching the little numbers tick up and seeing my charecter do well felt really rewarding (104 boxes red! ONE-OH-FOUR!) Theres also a fair bit of replay value as the choices you make can completely alter your story, you'll definatly get your moneys worth if you like this sort of thing.\nI really recommend this game to anyone who loves a good story thats not only funny, but hits you right in the feels with every choice you make.

reviewText:
Before I get into the review, I will try to spoil as little as poosible about the story. There will some MINOR SPOILERS, but I will mostly refer to the begining of the game, but ever so vague. Well, let us begin :)

Story: You are a character that has his/her life is in shambles and loses his/her boyfriend/girlfriend after the prologue of the game. Soon enough, you recieve an invitation to your ex's wedding ceremony that will occur in 30 days. It is your job to go get your ex back. Or is it?

Graphics: It's pixel art so what do you expect? Kidding aside, it suits the game quite nicely in my opinion.

Music: I love the music so much. Many songs will repeat, but you will never get tired of it, at least I didn't.

Gameplay: I did not say this before, but this game will not appeal to everyone because all you practically do is read. I see this game more as a Visual Novel rather than a game to be honest, but it is a really good one at that. There is a lot of text in the game, but with good reason. This game is all about choice. A lot of games that are out now have choices" in them
date: but this has to be the best game to deliver choice thus far in my opinion (Yes I have played Mass Effect 1-3 and Witcher 1-2 and I love them both if that means anything). Every choice you make
recommended: whether it being in dialogue or in action
hoursPlayed: it carries weight. What I love even more are that these choices are very subtle. There is no moral meter
voteText: light/dark
helpfulPercent:
or red/blue. All of the choices are grey and does not have a big sign showing "Make big decision here!!"
There are also various minigames to play to break the reading which are actually quite fun.

Pros:
+Story
+Music
+Gameplay
+CHOICES

Cons:
-Gameplay (I put it here twice because there is a lot of reading
votesHelpful:
but it didn't bother me)


In all

reviewText: Indie ♥♥♥♥ 0/10 worst game\n\nIn all seriousness, this game is pretty good for what it is. If you ever played The Sims 2 on PSP, it's akin to this in the sense you're just an ordinary person trying to do tasks to stay alive and accomplish your goal. Since there isn't too much in terms of complex gameplay, the game has to rely on its story, which is serviceable but nothing special. The RPG Maker artstyle works in this game and remains to be asthetically pleasing. The OST is pretty good too and keeps playing the game fun at least. While the choice aspect in this game leaves a bit to be desired, the choices themselves are well thought-out and do enough to at least make you think. I will say that this game is, at the very least, a unique experience and if you see it in a humble bundle or you have a little bit of money to spare, I would recommend getting this, or downloading the demo at least.

reviewText:
Never before have I been on the edge of wether or not to recommend this game.

As a traditional entertaining game, no, it's tedious and annoying when it actually comes to the game playing part.

The story line however is intriguing, and if your a big fan of playing out stories this is a good game to try. Never have I had a game make me cringe, especially a 2d rpg, the people's personalities, are like that from a novel, realistic but a bit over the top, it's not the annoying sunshine happy land and idiotic random remarks and comments you get from normal npc's in most games.

I still feel let down, and this will probably be a game I pick up and play when bored and have nothing to do, but for the 9$ I got it for, it's ok, and to all the people who undoubtedly will complain its not worth the price, it's the cost of a cup of coffee and a donut nowaday, if your to poor, dont buy it, it's a story about you.

reviewText:
****THIS REVIEW WILL HAVE MINOR SPOILERS*****

TL;DR. Buy it, its good.

Always Sometimes Monsters is all about choice. Will you be a nice guy/gal to everyone you meet, or will you steal  and cheat your way through? A basic plot synopsis would be you are a struggling writer who is kicked out of your apartment the day before you get a wedding invitation from your ex girl/boyfriend. You make it your mission to get to the wedding and jumpstart your career, but what you do along the way, and what happens when you get there, is up to you.

It has a really cool intro in picking your character. You will talk to a bunch of people at a party, and whoever you choose to take a drink with is your character. The same idea goes for your love interest. It has a very Pokemon-esque or RPG Maker like art style, one that I quite enjoy.

But it also has some very annoying mechanics. There is no mouse based support, all actions must be done through the keyboard. There is gamepad support, but I don't have one and therefore cannot comment on it. But to me a PC game where I can't use my mouse is really frustrating. Scaling the screen is also bugged right now. I could scale my screen down to a small resolution, but if I wanted it to go back, no amount of F6 would make it so unless I restarted. There are also typos and accidents galore in the text. For example, one time it called the same person a man and a woman, in the same line of dialogue.

But this game has plenty of positives. The choices you make in this game are everywhere. You never know how important a choice is, but it is amazing how much choice you really have. It mostly does boil down to a simple Fate system similar to a Fable-like morality, but quite enjoyable none-the-less. This bonanza of choice also means a replay is almost necessary. I loved seeing the different results my second time through. On my first blind playthrough it took about 10 hours, and I have played through it twice so far, and have no plans to stop now, despite the problems. Music and the soundtrack were nothing to write home about, and there is only around 6-7 songs, little to no sound effects, and no voice acting at all.


PROS AND CONS

+ Choice. It is what this game is all about, and they did a great job with it. There is at least three endings, and almost assuredly more.
+ Characters. While what you and your love interest look like is up to you, what you decide changes how people react to you. I was a lesbian couple in the first play and lots of people were uncomfortable with it in the game. Just a nice touch.

- Mechanics. As already described, this game could absolutely use some more time in the oven and smoothing of some edges. Lots of typos, and annoying systems.

OVERALL: 8/10. For only 9 or 10 dollars, this is a great pickup. But just be aware that at least as I am writing this, there are some problems that I hope get fixed.

reviewText:
Finished my first playthrough, and I have to say, I'm sad. This game made me hurt.

Now that that's out of the way, on to the actual review.

The game is split into several different towns that you move through on the way to win back your love. There is no tutorial, the game drops you into the world and immediately starts throwing punches, left and right. You get kicked out of your apartment and learn that your love is marrying someone else at the end of the month. The atmosphere of desperation is palpable as you struggle to rustle up enough cash for a bus ticket, though that's not the only way to get to San Verdano...

In terms of actual gameplay, Always Sometimes Monsters doesn't really offer much. The job missions tend to be repetitive and tedious - whether or not this was an intentional choice I'm unsure, but it certainly reflects the boredom such tasks would inflict in real life! The side missions that actually provide a modicum of entertainment value cost money and generally provide no reward for their completion. These, however, pale in comparison to the most glaring flaw in the entire design: the boxing minigame. In order to take a high road, you must complete this four-part debacle - it took me five days. There is no way to definitely win any given boxing match, as it is essentially a six-piece rock-paper-sickle game and you have to guess what sort of punch or dodge your opponent is going to use. Foes have tendencies, but don't always stick to them, so you can still be KOed due to a random anomaly.

These things aside, I was wrapped up in my journey across the country. The story pulled me in and made me feel for my character, tugging me further down the road - and here is where I found a flaw in the diamond, as it were: The journey felt so urgent and important that I hardly felt able to stop and look left or right. I often found myself with downtime between main quest missions, but side activities that didn't feel tedious and trite were difficult to find. The few times side missions were hinted, such as running into a frustrated woman at city hall and then again at the drug store, I couldn't figure out how to progess any further. The rest of the game felt bare-bones, without much content beyond the main quest.

Despite how negative this review looks, I would recommend this game - for the price and the experience, this is a worthwhile investment. The ending offers the opportunity for flawless victory and crushing defeat, and sadly, for me, mine was crushing defeat. To play this game, I think you need to not view it as a game, and instead try to step into the shoes of your character. Emphasis on the RP in RPG.

reviewText:
If you like games where the main character isn't some happy go lucky guy or super soldier from the future then this game is for you. You are in control of a main character who isn't clear cut good or bad and the choices you make aren't always so simple to make. Do you ruin another person's life to save another person life? Do you object taking a reward or do you take more than what someone says you can take? Do you stab someone in the back to get ahead or let your own life crumble to make someone else happy? The game often asks those kind of questions and expects you to answer. If you can accept that not every story has a happy ending then you probably can embrace this game cause chances are you probably won't get the Good Ending" on the first try but if you keep trying you should be able to. The story and the journey to find out how the end plays out are part of what makes this a good game and a different experience from other games out there.

I like how the game allows you to choose the main character and love interest in a way that isn't as simple as click this box for male or this box for female. Also this game does allow you to have same sex couples too for those that don't want to play as the straight couple. I wish there was a way to customize your character but there are a few varieties to choose from. For some of the major characters you can see their motivations and see the reasoning behind some of the things they do for better or worse as the game goes.

Some of the games drawbacks are that there doesn't seem to be a run button(You will wish that you can run sometimes)
date: the choices while sometimes in the grey area of right and wrong they don't always have positive or negative impacts on the world after the fact and don't make you like it mattered. Some of the choices do affect game though and in the end you have to answer for your choices and actions(Think last chapter of the Walking Dead videogame season 1) Some of the mini-games are fun and are nods to classic games(Like Frogger and Pac-Man)  however most of the jobs that you have do to earn cash are boring and repetive (I guess just like real life).\n\nFor this price I feel the game is worth while and you will be playing this game for several hours to try get the good ending for you and your love. Just be prepared to know that people are always sometimes monsters."

reviewText:
I'm a few hours into this game, and I haven't completed it yet. Just a little disclaimer about the review.

[THIS REVIEW MIGHT CONTAIN SPOILERS]

Basically, Always Sometimes Monsters puts you in the shoes of someone who is basically struggling to live above the poverty line after losing everything that made them truly happy - best friend, lover, job, all of it. Your job is to guide them through life and make choices for them that effect not only the life of your character, but the lives of those that surround your character as well.

Because the game tries to reflect life itself, parts of it get tedious and boring. That said, this game is very ambitious, and it has a few little meta jokes, which I liked. Always Sometimes Monsters has no right or wrong choices - this is not a game about the black and white parts of life, but the grey. You make a choice believing it's the right" one
date: but the next thing you know because you didn't make a different choice
recommended: the ♥♥♥♥'s hitting the fan. This is the kind of depressing existentialism you will find in this game - definitely NOT for everyone
hoursPlayed: but interesting and ambitious for a game nonetheless.\n\nThe game's concept is great
voteText: the ability to choose not only your gender but also your race and sexuality is an ambitious feature rarely seen elsewhere
helpfulPercent: and it adds an element of circumstance creating situations where even if you make all the "right" choices (or what you believe to be the right choices)

votesTotal: and your avatar's path will still change. The game is able to evoke an emotion

reviewText:
Always Sometimes Monsters is a fantastic, narritive-driven game where it feels like your decisions actually impact the story.  However, this feels like more of an adventure game than an RPG being that there is no actual character advancement.

The mini-games are subpar (but they are only mini-games, after all) - but they are, unfortunately, occasionally required.  In fact, a particular mini-game can bog down progression temporarily until you master it (or guess your way through it).  However, the actual story narritive is great, and you'll want to talk to every person you come across to uncover both humor and drama that are thickly spackled around the story of the actual protagonist - your protagonist.

So many decisions littered so liberally throughout the game and several ways the game can end lend to a good amount of replayability - in fact, you'll probably find yourself playing the game repeatedly just to see what might happen if you choose to behave a different way, or assist different people.

reviewText:
I'm a few hours into this game, and I haven't completed it yet. Just a little disclaimer about the review.

[THIS REVIEW MIGHT CONTAIN SPOILERS]

Basically, Always Sometimes Monsters puts you in the shoes of someone who is basically struggling to live above the poverty line after losing everything that made them truly happy - best friend, lover, job, all of it. Your job is to guide them through life and make choices for them that effect not only the life of your character, but the lives of those that surround your character as well.

Because the game tries to reflect life itself, parts of it get tedious and boring. That said, this game is very ambitious, and it has a few little meta jokes, which I liked. Always Sometimes Monsters has no right or wrong choices - this is not a game about the black and white parts of life, but the grey. You make a choice believing it's the right" one

reviewText:
A dude got killed because of swag and I avenged him.

That aside, this is a really nice game and I recommend it.
I really liked the mechanics--the hustling. I see the game as a moral playground: you're free to apply whatever morality and ethics you want in the safe environment of a fictional world, and see how that turns out.
Of course the game gives you a goal, and there is where it gets itchy. The game assumes you care about the goal. I didn't, despite the various flashbacks. Nevertheless, I got the message clear.

reviewText: If I would use one word to explain Always sometimes monsters" it would be intresting. You start in the beginning of the game choosing (not creating) your hero and your special someone
date: and the first thing that supprised me in this game was that you can choose gender and if the relation is beetween two girls or guys or one of each and still not affect the story (except some spelling errors). You then start the game after one year (after you selected your hero) just to find out that your significant other has left you and she will get married in the end of the month (and you are invited). But you are broke and it is a long way to the wedding
recommended:
which means that you need to get money and it is here the game becomes intresting.

During your journey through the land (well a part of the land) you will meet many choices that can challange your ethics but you will gain money becouse of it and you will note everything in a journal (to be honest it's up to you if you want to write in it or not at the end of the day in the game). Which even if you think that what you do is not so bad it might be so much worse than you thinked.

The story has multiply endings and how it ends depends on you. The music in this game is good but not great and there are some systems in the game I think could be better like the boxing system that can feel quite randomly or at least thats how it felt for me. The music in the game is good but can be a little repetativ. if there was something I wish was in this game it would be a run function becouse I wanted to go faster sometimes.

some tips when playing the game is that when you choose a hero and a speciall someone
hoursPlayed: pick gender and names like the real life version of you and your significant other (girlfriend/boyfriend
voteText:
crush or Husband or wife). Personally I think that will help you get into the game and a better understanding for what you would do for her or him. But thats just something I think would help the game experience.

With all that said I give "Always sometimes monsters" an 8/10 = great game. I could not stop playing before I was done but I only recomend this game to people who have patience doing chores sometimes (becouse the events in each town has a limit) so with that said I have one final question before I end this.

How far are you willing to go for your significant other?"

reviewText: I've certainly gotten my $9 worth from this game.  I've spent two days playing it and several hours thinking about it.  Much better value than the $13.50 I paid to see Godzilla.  Exploring is fun, all the choices are interesting, (I only wish there were more) and the subject matter gives your decisions a lot of weight.  I agonized over some of the things I had my character do in the game.  I'm already thinking about the choices I will make in my next playthrough.  There are frustrating moments, but they usually serve to advance the story.  Overall, if you want an RPG you can fall into for a few days and that will stay with you for awhile, Sometimes Always Monsters fits the bill.

reviewText: You're a lesbian writer living in an East L.A. city who gets kicked out of her apartment by Mr. Rodgers and you’re trying to stop the wedding of your ex so you end up selling dogs to a dogfighting ring and giving handjobs in the back of pet stores to afford an $800 bus ticket. You then play as a black man who looks like a young Forest Whitaker who doesn’t really do anything other than walk around and talk to rich people. Always Sometimes Monsters is a great example of the overbearing upper class fighting the liberal youth of the underprivileged children of the urban cities and if you are looking for a deep, complex social analysis of modern racial struggles I would recommend this game.

reviewText:
It's nice to finally have a game where there is no perfect avenue of choices. Like real life there's no perfect option with each choice having it's benefits and drawbacks where you have to simply choose and hang on for the ride. There's also no real karma meter to judge you.

Granted this game is far from perfect for example being a bit too vague about some of the crossroads in the story you can take, how overblown a few certain situations are and the repetative job-grinding for money but this game has many good points as well like putting you in the shoes of just an everyday person like you and me and forcing the player to make the difficult choices. It's a refreshing change of pace from the usual save the world RPGs that flood the field these days. Also the soundtrack is rather nice.

Overall, rough around the edges but this is for sure worth a play

reviewText:
I find it hard to get immersed in games that are story-centric, and this game is very much that.

All the same, it's easy to tell, there's something special in this game, as the devs have put a lot of love into building a believable world filled with characters who say and do things that wouldn't be expected of sprites like these.

It's a good game to snag, if you're looking for a story driven experience that provides surprises and lots of wtf?" moments.

Recommended."

reviewText: The whole concept of the game is very different so the main crowd of gamers today might not like this game its very niche. The reason I love it is because it is different. reviewText:
this game is so realistic it's scary.... what supernatural force must the developers have conjured to be able to come up with a game that matches my life that closely...

i started out by accidentally falling into a lesbian relationship and book deal.... then find myself homeless and determined to etch out an honest living and keep to myself. all seems to be going well until i feel feel itchy feet and decide to move again... in my new town i automatically get in the middle of couples fights, end up in the loony bin,  get molested, make trades until a drug dealer breaks me out and afterward get a job loading trucks... granted the job loading trucks paid $150 a day and i only got paid $100 a week for that in real life, and rent in this game is dirt cheap but i wont argue semantics. after that i made friends with my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ boss because i understand those people...

and now i'm kinda scared to play any farther...

i don't know if i should recommend this, i play video games to escape reality and so far this isn't giving me any wiggle room.. but until i end up a sex slave in a seedy motel i guess it still leaves me enough room to dream about a normal life...

reviewText: Pretty much a choose-your-own adventure game except with an incredibly vast number of decisions you can make. The biggest problem, though, is that there is no actual adventure. The first 20 minutes were just mundane, random minutiae. Nothing happened. Also, the dialogue is poorly written, the art is ugly, the engine is painfully bad, and the music is boring and repetitive. I could a very certain type of person who would like this game- someone who spends a lot of time roleplaying on Gaia Online and writes lots of Harry Potter fanfic. That someone is not me.

reviewText: A great branching adventure game where your choices really impact the way to game plays out, both leading up to the ending and the ending itself. It can be serious and grim at times but it also has a good sense of humour at the right times. General gameplay reminds me of Shenmue, walking around and talking to people, performing jobs and (optionally) collecting figurines but the story and themes are more mature.\n\nIf you like adventure games and story driven games where your choices impact what happens, this game is definitely worth playing.

reviewText:
This game have an interesting prologue. You lost your love, your job, and even your home at the beginning of the game, and you will have to do whatever you can to get them back. This game is all about choice and consequence. How far would you go to get the life you want?

There're lots to do in game. Trying to figure out how to maxmize profit can be interesting. Although there will be times when you have to do lots of saving and loading in order to get everything right (especially near end game). Trying to make different choices and see how things turn out differently is also what make this kind of games interesting too.

Although I think the game is fun as a whole, I feel that the character development is weak. Sure they are all interesting, but they are not convincing. To a certain degree, I don't see how the 'past story' can explain or to support the development of the later story. I'm confused and question the actions/reactions of the main characters later in the game. There are so many gaps you have to fill in yourself. The story feels a bit rush and tries to push things forward during the second half of the game. It is a pretty major weakness considering this is a highly story driven game.

Other than that, this game still gave me a good experience.

reviewText:
When I first played this game I wasn't too impressed.
Then I played some more, and some more, some more.... ♥♥♥♥, this game is addicting!
So many choices, so many consequences, so many characters and on top of it all; a great storyline!

I would say this is by far ONE of the most enjoyable games i've been playing in a while.
I highly recommend this game for those who loves to be handed a lot of choices and are a fan of a (as i wrote before) great storyline.

The only bad thing (in my opinion) about this game is that it became kind of repetive from time to time.

9/10

reviewText:
PROS:
Pixelated Graphics
RPG Style Game
Story Driven
All choices have consequences and effect outcome

CONS:
Story Driven
Very little interaction besides reading, selecting dialog options, and traveling
Little gameplay
Essentially a digitized pick your adventure book

I truly wanted to love this game, it's made by Devolver after all, and I loved hotline Miami.  Unfortunately, the only things the two share are their music style, graphical stylings, and developer.

For those looking for a story-heavy RPG Maker experience, this would be right up your alley.  I got this as part of a Humble Bundle, so I don't mind the price I paid for it.  However, given the number of free RPGMaker games out there in this similar style, you may be better off with the free alternatives.

reviewText: 7/10: As a struggling writer who receives an invitation to the imminent marriage of your ex, your only hope for a career hinges on handing in the journal you are writing as you struggle to get across the country in time for it. Things get problematic" as they are wont to do for protagonists.\n\nThe game begins with what I did not realize was a character selection process. In choosing who to take a drink from and who they talk to outside
date: you are in fact setting up not only yourself but your significant other as well! After that initial party where you get signed though
recommended: you soon find out things have not been going so smoothly for you. As a player
hoursPlayed: you get to step in just as you're getting evicted and utterly broke.\n\nAt its core
voteText: this is a narrative game that tasks the player with accumulating enough money via interactions to proceed to the next scene. Still
helpfulPercent: only a fraction of events that deal with story and character development really earn you the money you need
votesHelpful: so a good portion of the games "challenge" feels like grinding as you put in double shifts at the factory. Still
votesTotal: I didn't really feel challenged by the tasks so much as obligated to deal with them for the sake of the story.\n\nThat being said
votesFunny: the story is interesting. The story may shift dark or light depending on how you choose to approach the issue of dealing with people and situations along the way to the wedding
commentsCount: but the central theme of love and loss stays the same regardless. Any more than that would be spoiling it though.\n\nAs far as advice
column16: I suggest buying a fishing rod as soon as possible in Dubstown. It's about $100
column17: but fishing lets you avoid wasting money on food
column18: which helped speed things up a bit for me. Also
column19: once you finish whatever stories you have in an area
column20: just work morning and afternoon shifts at local temp agencies. The Tofu Factory in Dubstown and the Grow Op in Beaton seem to be the most profitable
column21: but you can try investing in the Sandwich Stock Market on the side or gambling to get some money too. Also
column22: collecting all the Indie Heroz figurines gets you nothing!\n\nOverall
column23: it's a good story of love and what one may do for it. Maybe you think that love is all you need to justify becoming a fiend. So how many of your morals would you compromise to see them again?"

reviewText:
This game has flaws, but I think it's succeeds in what it's trying to do. While the gameplay is not particularly fun or memorable, it's intresting to see the way you play out a whole section of someone's life, and where it goes. The story isn't always particularly exciting or engaging, but it's still imersive in some way. The main reason I like this game so much is it's a  step away from a lot of common place things in games, like leveling up and health bars and constant battles or puzzles. It's an attempt at interactive art, and while it doesn't do anywhere near as other attempts at similar concepts I've played *cough*Too The Moon*cough* It's still worth some money and atleast a few hours.



Maybe get it on sale or in a bundle if you can, though.

reviewText:
This game is okay. Right now, it's on sale, which is when I decided to pick it up. Paying $10 for an RPG maker game with no replay value seems very silly, so I got it for $5 instead. It's a fun game, however your game is going to spent with tedious mini games, trying to earn as much  money as you can just for a good ending. I had no idea, so I'm stuck gambling. I recommend using more than one save file.

I dislike the autosave feature. I also dislike that there's no option to turn off music (I looked, or maybe I just missed it.) So be prepared to have your own back ground soundtrack ready because the music is loud and obnoxious when you'd rather have something soothing or quiet. Not much changes depending on your gender or sexual orientation, though I like that you at least have the option to be a man or woman and gay or straight. That's cool with me!

I think it's a good game to play once, but like I said before-- it has no replay value. I wouldn't recommend paying full price for it.

reviewText: Don't get me wrong, this game has it's moments and is worth $5, but I'm just here to warn you that this is not a choose your own adventure, this game gives you the illusion of choice for everything, but those choises do NOT matter.  There are almost never consiquences in this game for making a moraly bad decision (like killing someone or stealing their life savings).  This game also gives you the illusion of being a long game by having many moments of walking back and forth LITERALY FOR HOURS.  There are points that in order to finish I had to spend 2 and a half hours walking back and forth pressing space-bar so the game would continue.  This is less of a game of making decisions and more of a 'playable' movie, only you aren't playing the movie, but a completly seperate game. meow.  If you have $5 you feel like using then buy it, if not, don't waist your money or time.

reviewText:
Its a choose your own adventure game threaded  together using ALOT of boring minigames. being able to choose how you want to deal with situations presented in the game is the best part, but sometimes I saw my choices didn't save (ie. Someone died, they're alive later). The story was an interesting idea, most of the conversations with characters were pretty great and well written, however some conversations and story points made me go wtf, didn't make sense, or was just badly thought out and written. I like the changing settings and how there were at least 3 full towns to explore, however lacking towards the end in SV. Now as a choose your adventure/choice game I would recommend it hesitantly.

BUT absolute worst thing this game does is create a very long amount of trash filler minigames to tie the story together.
From my playthrough I played 3 arcade minigames (one pacman ripoff), 2 job minigames (Tofu/Weed jobs), coat check minigame, box minigame, hacking minigame (frogger ripoff), vent maze, deliver drugs minigame, boxing minigame, 4 casino minigames. I hated them. Almost all the minigames I listed are required for progress or jobs done to progress the day. By the end of the game, I've had enough and didn't even play any of the casino minigames cause that's a stupid idea. I hated those boring minigame segments that are half the game.

Also, the developer cameo was great at first in the coffee shop, but wtf was with the two of them, and that ending at the book store was so stupidly bad I laughed.

Do not recommend.

reviewText:
My overall opinion: A pretty good game, it won't be liked by some people but I gotta say the story and the choices you make/say really did feel like a real choice and the ending wasn't set in stone and there are quite a few ways your journey may end earlier or differently

(WARNING! THERE ARE SOME HINTED SPOILERS!)

(This Is Just My Own Personal Opinion And How I Felt The Game Was To Me And You Might Feel Different To My Point Of View So Please Be Nice Kay? =)

It wasn't a game where you can just get the best ending by just rushing to the end and picking the right dialog, it was focused on choices and life decisions that can cause your own story to end suddenly by taking the wrong turn in life.

There are some flaws that I felt made the game feel annoying at some points like the boxing minigame or earning enough income in a short time open up another dialog option later in the story but without knowing all this beforehand you'll be left with just one thing, your own personal choice. (and this is without being a cheat and reading a how-to guide!)

The epilogue felt open ended and you cannot revisit the previous town/cities to check up on how they are all doing and your main love interest (if you choose to persue it) simply locks him/herself in a room and you end up having a limit set of options you could do.

I truely wished there was abit more to the story in the epilogue, I kinda felt cheated after going through everything just to have my main love interest lock him/herself in so I cannot see or talk to him/her and having it end just like that because I felt there could be abit more story between the main character and the love interest rather than relying mostly on flashback/dreams and maybe having them go together to revisit the town/cities the main character have gone to and see where it goes from there.

Heres hoping for dlc or a sequel! but I doubt they'd do that, happens too often~ =P

Anyways, this is a good game in which I will play again to see what else it has to offer and the main theme of the game is probably the choice in life and maybe something else =P , I hope you enjoy it if you do buy the game, its total recommended game to get!

reviewText:
I've just finished it, and I kinda don't know what to say.

It was funny and rather engrossing. In the middle, I thought the game was going to take a downturn, but it didn't. It totally held my interest the whole way through. They do a good job of both doing a (sort of) life sim and telling their story (trying to get a few cities away, with no money, to go to your ex's wedding).

Huge plus points for the fact that you get to pick both your gender AND your partner's gender. It really is a massive perk to me to be able to play gay in a game (and, probably had a bit to do with my level of engrossed as well).

I really have nothing bad to say about this game. Well written, funny, sweet, tender, it packs a lot into its environments and populates them with interesting characters, some of who's stories I never got to the end of (FK, for example, I wonder what happened there). Much like life. And the way they tie in the end with the beginning (which I had forgotten all about) is great.

A huge factor to note is the moral dilemma's that the game throws up. One minor example, for example, some girl asks you to buy her drugs. You can take her money and buy her the real stuff, or spend part of her money, give her fakes and keep the change, which was what I did. But the next time I saw her, she was woozy and sick and I felt really guilty (and also lost an avenue to the game, which I didn't realise until checking later!). So yeah, some choices have big affect, some don't, and like life, you never know which is which.

Tldr; Just buy the thing and enjoy being a struggling writer who lost the love of his life and is doing everything he can to get back to him. Quirky, well-drawn (in both senses of the word), well-written, varied story-driven game. I'm already eagerly awaiting their next game!

reviewText: This was a game that, after seeing many reviews and recommendations from friends and family, I finally purchased and played through myself. I am not disappointed in that purchase. It is by no means a perfect or flawless game and at times I did feel a bit frustrated, especially when I was trying to gather money just to keep my Stamina up, but I felt that the story was intriguing enough to keep me pulled in.\n\nAt first, some of the missions and things you do seem pointless or unrewarding but they ARE worthwhile. Another big thing is that I found it extremely helpful to have multiple save files. The biggest thing to remember is that there are many different paths you can walk in this game than the one that is directly presented in front of you.

reviewText: I heard some great things about the writing, the storyline and how  you choices and actions would affect things.  After four hours, I feel like that time was wasted.  There is a lot of money grinding and action grinding to push the stages along, and the caricatures disguised as people have become insufferable.  Nothing really felt like it was having any effect on the overall story, and realizing that the main plot of this game is really to profess the fact I can't get over my ex after a year and do it them on their wedding day is a trope and a somewhat pathetic story when used in B-List Rom-Com movies.\n\nI really wanted more, and after only reading the reviews at this point, it doesn't sound like I will get anything more out of it.  I finish this glad this was within a HumbleBundle, so I do not feel as though any money was spent on this.
