reviewText:
Here is a good system to determine if you should get this game:

1. Have you played To the Moon? If yes, go to 3. If no, go to 2,
2. Play To the Moon, go to 3
3. Did you like To the Moon? If yes, go to 4. If no, go to 6.
4. Are you a masochist who would genuinely enjoy a depressing and hopeless story that makes you feel lower than the dirt in the gutter that you step over on your way to work every day? If yes, go to 5. If no, go to 6.
5. Play this game...and enjoy being miserable.
6. Liberate tuteme ex inferis. (Save yourself from hell)

Imagine, if you will, if To the Moon and Tell Tale's the Walking Dead had a baby...and then both parents immediately died after the birth to leave the child in the care of Spec Ops: The Line. That child would grow up to become Always Sometimes Monster.

tl;dr - the above is all you need as far as a recommendation is concerned

Im seriously on the fence about whether to truly recommend this game. On one hand, it is well written and has a genuinely engaging story. On the other, it makes me want to shove glass under my fingernails as penance for ruining everybody's lives.

Youll notice I mentioned To the Moon a lot and for good reason: this game feels like it came from the same developer. Its an 8-bit retro game thats pretty much a serving plate for a really good story (To the Moon was infinitely better, though). You dont sit down to enjoy the plate; the plate is just the method of delivering the food (aka the story). And boy does this food taste like depressing sadness cooked in a fine horrible-people wine...

*spoilers* *spoilers* *spoilers* *spoilers* ...and rants below

Dont say I didnt warn you. 2 final thoughts/rants (on the story):

This game presents itself as a decision based game...its a dirty liar. All of the story elements happen irrespective to your decisions, and in more than one situation I actually had my decisions hyped up as being super important and then the game pretended like the decision never happened. One particular moment stands out:

Youre offered to either spend 3 days hunting down 3 car parts through tedious side-quests to fix up a car and win a race...or spend one afternoon to cut the opponent dude's brake line and have him burst into flames literally right in front of his 4 little children (I was in a hurry, dont judge me...though it was hilarious after the fact). The next day, the guy who put you in the situation in the first place, set up the race, a true blue Christian from head to toe, is a pastor at the church, and LITERALLY just presided over the dead dude's funeral with his little children crying DADDY NOOO" goes up to you and acts like nothing happened and is like "Hey! Ready for that car trip Whatsyourface?" in the most cheery way possible. The decision is only mentioned once more in one of the game's many random pointless questionnaires that means absolutely nothing about whether you regret your decision. Consequences? In a game based entirely around consequences?! Pfft

reviewText: This title first and foremeost had a very solid style of delivery and it's soundtrack was really nice. On the onset of the game you have the choice of selecting your own main protaganist and their significant other before the game launches you into its main story. Filled with countless moral decisions that render a few different endings. It's story is pretty good with a lot of random sidequests/minigames that help propel itself forward. Overall, it was a pretty interesting style of delivery and character development. Only thing that sort of fell through was the ending. It just felt as if it had a really fun buildup (9  hours of it) only to deliver a really short and swift ending. In the end the final decisions help you decide what your sense of a 'monster' is. But seeing how exactly you or the other characters impact eachother is kinda of shortsighted. Still a fine title 6.5/10

reviewText:
The one thing this game has going for it is that you can tell it was a labor of love.  It feels very personal, as if the developers created it without the intention of showing it to anyone else, and there's something charming about that.

Unfortunately, the awkward writing, the nonsensical plot, and especially the really tedious gameplay (culminating in having to gamble up to a ridiculous amount of money to get the best ending) are too much.  There were several pretty annoying glitches, one where events weren't triggered at the right time and resulted in seeing the same dialogue more than once, and one where a minigame was just completely broken.  I also found it way too easy to accidentally select dialogue choices when hitting the button to advance through the text.

But as I said, there's something kind of charming about it.  So I played through almost all of the game until I reached the part I described in the spoiler, and then I just decided it wasn't worth the time and looked up the endings.  I can't say I didn't enjoy it, there were moments where the writing was actually great, but I can't really recommend buying it.  Perhaps watch a playthrough on Youtube so you can skip the tedious parts.

reviewText:
So, I was really excited for this game. I saw the initial trailer and thought that it looked great. I kept an eye on it when it was released, but it was a little bit more than I like to pay for games. When I saw that it was included in a Humble Bundle, I jumped at the chance to get it.

If you can stand the thought of an RPG without combat of any sort, and you like to read a LOT, I recommend this game. I wouldn't exactly call it an RPG, though. It's more like a Choose-Your-Own-Adventure book. You move through the story, making moral decisions and seeing the results.

The gameplay and writing starts out very strong. The story quickly hooks you in, and there's a lot to see and do in Dogstown, the first area. However, each area after that has a little less detail and fewer interesting things to do. It seems like the writers started out strong and then ran out of steam.

The game is actually pretty short. I finished it in just under 9 hours. There is some replay value in it (making different choices to get different endings), but not really a ton.

I'd give it a 7 out of 10 rating. I like the philosophical area that the game designers were trying to explore, but they have this weird love/hate relationship with the story tropes they use. They present some pretty cliche tropes, but then they don't reward your for following through it them.

Random thoughts:
-For the love of GOD, can there be more than a single microwave in the damn game?!?! I finished the game with the same three HotPockets that I started with, because the only microwave is in your starting apartment. There are NO microwaves in any of the convenience stores, none in the apartment you stay in, none in the trailer and none in the house!

-From the inital previews, they made it sound like you could choose any race/gender/orientation to play. You can, but the initial character selection process is VERY unclear. They needed to add more information about what you're choosing when you 'toast' people in the first scene.

-One thing that really bothered me was your 'best friend'. Throughout the game, you are told this character is your best friend and there's nothing you wouldn't do for each other. However, you are never given any reason why this is, and you don't get to see much of the relationship that made them friends. Building a rapport with this characters is pretty crucial to the later parts of the story, so the writers needed to Show
recommended: and they missed out on doing that."

reviewText:
I have very mixed feelings about this game, so let's go into it.

At first, it seemed to be a game about choices, with a deep, rich and ever-changing storyline, in which every little decision could change one's fate. But a quick internet search proves the opposite. Looking back, I can see that (virtually) every decision one makes in this game is about profiting money or not, and the choices made by the player change more about the NPCs lives than their own. I also could not yet understand how the very beginning of the game, the part with the mafioso guy, relates to everything else. In conclusion, the developers could have had put a lot more effort into the storyline, as it can be pretty deceiving, and the teaser video is also very misleading.

On the other hand, if one does not care very much about the storyline they can enjoy the game for a while. The pixel graphics and sprites are very well-made, but could have been better if the developers have used less colours and some dithering. The close-up of the characters are sometimes too anime-ish and ordinary and do not fit the game style. The soundtrack is the part which I have little or  nothing to complain about, and can act as a filler for the feelings that the story fails to deliver.

Talking about system requirements, this game needs a lot of disk space (320MB+) compared to it's graphics (here comes in the dithering and limited colour palettes I talked about, it could have reduced the image size A LOT). Sound could also have been better compressed, and the developers could have stuck to just one sound algorithm, instead of using both MP3 and OGG. This game is also very CPU and RAM demanding, and will probably not run in older or “weaker” machines. But I think that this all is because of RPG Maker. I also could not make the game fullscreen, as it would just lose the window borders and stay the same size. Doubling the window size makes the graphics lose quality due to interpolation. I also could not take screenshots with the Steam hotkey (F12) as the game would just crash or quit to the title screen. But I think these problems are caused by Wine.

Last thing is that Always Sometimes Monsters really lacks a tutorial or a key setup menu. The player isn't really supposed to know the controls beforehand and has to guess them.

After all, I feel that I cannot relate or empathize with this game's plot, and that's just because it is pretty shallow, linear and filled with “gratuitous violence” (like lots of people dying all the time). As the first game I bought on steam it was a very disappointing experience. I'll try to finish the game with at least one character, but I think this game is not really worth my time.

Long story short:

Graphics: 7/10 – Nice pixel graphics, but sometimes seeming out of place;
Soundtrack: 8/10 – The best part of this game is the soundtrack;
Story: 2/10 – Could have been much better if the developers had put a bit of effort into it;
System: 1/10 – Consumes way too much computing resources, there are better games out there which are less resource-hungry.

Overall: 4,5/10

P.S.: I apologize for any spelling error or weird sentences, as English is not my first language.

reviewText:
Surprisingly catchy!

I got this game out of a humble bundle, and I started playing it without ever looking at the store page. It is very confusing, because it is unlike most of the other games you can find on the market.

This is a game about life. Somewhat like The Sims, but this isn't about building a stable life, but rather about surviving a difficult life for a month, and try to get back the love of your life. Also much darker than the sims.

At first it will be boring and annoying, just like life. You need money to live, you need to work to get money, and nobody likes to work. But in the middle of these boring, work-filled days, you will be faced with several defining choices... And the next thing you know, you finished the game, and you feel like you just finished watching a really good movie or reading a really good book. And even though it is only a bunch of pixels, and not even particularly realistic, you will feel guilty for behaving like a real monster.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game; I forced myself to play for almost 15 hours of it and just can’t bring myself into playing anymore. For a story driven game it has shockingly bad writing. The game is about the struggles we face in everyday life, yet the story was completely detached from reality. I mean, there are actions can potently lead to the deaths of multiple people without any repercussions, even though you *spoiler alert* wrote it into a journal which you published into a book!

And you know the scene in the dark alley at the start? That’s what got me to keep playing because I wanted to see how the rest of the game tied in to it. Guess what? It doesn’t. Those characters showed up at the very end, and are completely shoed in to justify the first scene.

The writing is also extremely pretentious. It spends too much time talking about philosophy of right and wrong, rather than showing through their action of its character. Which is a wasted opportunity, as many characters has potential for development (like Mark). The saying “show, don’t tell” really applies here.

The gameplay is pretty much non- existence. Which is fine in “To the Moon” (another story-driven rpg-maker game), because it’s short and to the point. While in this game, I spend 15 hours in this game and still haven’t finished it (I watched a let’s play if you are wondering how I know the ending). It is drawn out and tedious, which would have been okay if the story was good, but it wasn’t.

All this would have been forgivable if the developers weren’t so ♥♥♥♥ing pleased with themselves. It’s okay to be proud of your work; it’s also okay put yourself in the game as a character.  What isn’t okay is *spoiler alert* to have a book in the game called “Always Sometimes Monsters” and calling it a masterpiece, and saying that “nothing captures the human spirit quite so well” which it clearly doesn’t, and of yourself show up to offer the author  1 million dollars to turn it into a game.

With all that said I hope they learn their lesson and make a better game next time, games like this are few and far between.

reviewText:
Always Sometimes Monsters is an RPG developed by Vagabond Dog to simulate survival in modern society whilst driving forward a constant storyline revolving around your chosen character and partner that you choose at the beginning of the game. The responsibility of choosing your own way in life and making important decisions really grabbed my attention when playing through this. It is not your average RPG in which you play a linear story making choices that don't necessarily affect the state of the world and the relationships you have with the people in it, Infact, the choices you make will definately affect the world around you and the way that you are treated by other characters definately towards the end of the game.

The visuals are pretty standard for an RPG of this type, but the attention to detail is definately worth a mention, If you want an interesting visual experience and a great story, this game can definately provide you with both. There are a few graphical problems, particularly with the Hospital Lobby area, the food plates seem to be hovering in mid air and are being eaten by people standing at the ends of the table instead of being sat at it, I don't know if this is a known problem, or if vagabond intend to deal with it, but it isn't an experience ruiner for sure, so don't let it affect your opinion too badly.

The music in this game is incredibly atmospheric, and provides a lot of mood setting for the particular towns and areas. The Laser Destroyer Team did a great job on it and they should be proud of the masterpieces that they produced. One of my favourite tracks is 'Hit the Town', and I suggest you give those a listen if you're into 8-bit themes.

TOTALS:
Graphics: 6/10
Sound: 9/10
Story: 9.5/10 (Absolutely insanely good, but not perfect in every way)
Polised? --Couple of minor scratches 8/10
32.5/40
Overall experience rating: Garunteed memorable game!

RPG lovers will love such a personal and exciting experience ;3" - Bunnieth
"

reviewText:
I've really tried to enjoy this game, specially after reading so many positive reviews about it. I enjoy story based games, and the premise sounded promising enough to catch my attention. But I can't do it, I can't keep going on.

I'll start by saying that I don't mind the graphics, or the RPG-Maker, or the really crappy sound effects. And if I have to point out something positive, I'll say that the music is pretty decent.

But the story... It tries to hook you up in a plot of moral dilemmas and hard choices, about a young person out of luck, alone in the cold, uncaring world. But every time the game was about to catch me in it, a blatant change of tone, terrible inconsistencies would break any immersion I was having.

The game tries to be dramatic and emotional, but any kind of tension is completely diluted by continuous 4th wall breakings, silly jokes and unnecessary collectables.

It also tries to sell you that your decisions matter, but they hardly do. For example, at one point, you might not have enough money to pay for a room, and find yourself sleeping in the streets. Which at first I thought it'd be terrible and a real handicap while trying to find a job and get back on my feet, turned to have absolutely no consequences.  You'd think that sleeping under the stars, among the hobos, not being able to take showers or change your clothes would have any negative effects in your health or social status, but no. You search for food in a trash can, heat it up in a burning barrel and sleep on a dirty mattress in a creepy alley, and then go to work as a top notch reporter in the local newspaper, then go dance at the expensive club at night. Just before you go back to sleep to your hobo alley. By the time I had enough money to rent a room, I didn't even consider doing it, because there was no point in doing so, at least, that I could see!

And on top of that, to get money, you have to do little mini games that are absolutely tedious. And I've played Papers, Please, and Cart Life, games that played on routine and struggling with your life every day, and enjoyed it. I couldn't keep playing Always Sometimes Monsters.

reviewText: You are a writer struggling to make ends meet and life keeps screwing you over. You get kicked out of your apartment, you have to work menial jobs to make barely enough to feed yourself, and your significant other left you. You receive their wedding invitation in the mail and decide to make your way across the country to get there in time, but what happens along the way is really up to you. It's a game about choice, consequences, and asking the question of what matters and what you decide to live for. It does a wonderful job and I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
I don't do too many reviews for the games I play, but I felt this one really deserved it. Always Sometimes Monsters has one of the best stories I have ever had the pleasure of experiencing in a video game. The story is so incredibly humanizing and endearing; for me, it hit (perhaps a bit too much) close to home.

While the story is fantastic, the mechanics are not. The minigames. Oh, God, the minigames. The combo boxing and the black jack were clunky and obtuse, becoming nothing more than spamming choices and reloading when that didn't work out.

Would I recommend it though? Absolutely

reviewText:
I really want to be able to recommend this game....but I can't. Always Sometimes Monsters has a lot of potential but is just lacking overall. The pace is juuuuust slow enough to be considered a hindrance, and while it is definitely a game that makes you think about the morality of your choices, there's a final step it isn't taking. In the end nothing really ends up having consequence. I got it half off so it's not like I'm upset about buying it, and honestly I think I would have been okay paying $10 even because it does have a lot of good qualities. But overall it sits pretty neutral with me so if I had to say yes or no, I'd say no- the bottom line is you're not missing a life changing experience by NOT playing this.

I'm not completely done and I do plan to finish and maybe play again to see if much changes depending on your choices, but I'm far enough along where I'm pretty sure my feelings won't change by the end. Again, the game isn't awful by any means, but I can't exactly justify raving over it.

One thing that did really frustrate me though: the game quits when you try to take a screenshot! Another review had stated this but stupid me tried to do it anyway, and of course I was right in the middle of something...waaaay annoying. I wonder if this is something with games made in RPG Maker? because To The Moon does the same thing...except instead of quitting the game pauses, which I think is a thing Always Sometimes Monsters could use to incorporate to save some frustration.

reviewText:
If I could have given this game a neutral rating I would have, but since I have to pick one I’ve gone with recommending it.

ASM certainly got me hooked at the start – the freedom of character choice was good, and it seemed like there was a lot to do. From Day 1, there are quite a few options available to you, and many choices you can make. The game claims to run on a system where every small choice affects you, but in the end that doesn’t really happen.

The games plot is linear – no matter which decisions you make, you always end up travelling between certain places to make your way towards your ex’s wedding, although there are a few options on how to do that dictated by what your do in the places you visit. A lot of short side missions never really do anything – the phrase “You’re a good friend” appears several times throughout the story, but these characters never really do anything else afterwards. One of the side missions even seems like it’s going to reappear near the end (when it turns out a big event happening at the same time as the wedding is one you can win a pass to for someone) but that doesn’t go anywhere, the kid you help out is completely missing from the last arc. No matter your actions, you’ll end up in the final situation where all that happens is you might have locked yourself out of the endings.

Speaking of the endings… my main gripe with this game is that they’re unsatisfying. Endings don’t necessarily need to be happy, but all of the outcomes for ASM leave a sour taste in one’s mouth. To start off with, the stamina system (which exists solely to keep you spending money on food or fishing) means that if you go to sleep when it’s too low, game over. It’s far too abrupt. Obviously it doesn’t need to be dramatic, but a little cutscene of what happens during the night would help rather than the screen flashing “YOU DIED IN YOUR SLEEP” and taking you back to the title screen. I presume something similar happens if you manage to waste enough time to miss the wedding – although there may be some event that forces you to get there anyway. As for the main endings, some of them flat out don’t work – such as you becoming a millionaire but inexplicably becoming a hobo, and others just see that characters don’t work together. Even the ‘perfect’ ending sees your love hint at being discontent with the situation, before leaving you in a pointless epilogue which seems to exist just so you can play the video games freely or try and hit up a high score in time spent in the shower, which could have been accomplished by adding an extra option to the title screen upon completion.
The moral of the game seems to be that you either have to screw people over or be a successful gambler to make any money. I disagree with it but I understand why the developers have done it.

However, for all its flaws, I did enjoy the game (sans the ending.) Of the 10 or so hours I put into it, I enjoyed most of them – the story is nothing spectacular, but it’s enjoyable. The graphics aren’t the best and the music choice is all over the place but I still liked playing it (even if most of the time was spent save scumming on scratch cards, races and casinos.) The developers insert themselves from time to time and there are other brief moments of humour which certainly help with the experience.

All in all, ASM claims that it presents a story which is heavily decided by the choices you make. As you’d expect, this isn’t the case because that would be a development nightmare. Despite that, the game is mostly enjoyable despite having a bitter aftertaste due to the unsatisfying endings. While I don’t think Vagabond Dog have hit it off with this game, it looks like there is a lot of potential so I’ll probably keep an eye out to see what else they’ve got in store in the future.

reviewText:
Always Sometimes Monsters is a story driven game following the life of your character trying win back their love. The choices made in the game are generally black and white, but some are quite vague that you only truly realise what you've done after you've made your choice. Some of the choices you make will have an effect on the game, some minor and others major, but the most important choices you make are determined by how much money you have and not by the choices you make.

The story however is the reason you should buy this game. It isn't about you killing monsters or curb stomping zombies, it's a story about fighting for what you love and fighting to survive, making choices good and bad and taking risks just to complete your goal.

The art style and music of the game is great if you love a bit of nostalgia or like RPG maker games, it's nothing too fancy but it gets the job done.

So if you love a good story driven game, the I reccomend giving Always Sometimes Monsters a go. If not, you can always wait until it's on sale. I picked it up from a Humble Bundle for $1 afterall.

reviewText:
First, and most importantly, you should not go into this with any preconcieved notions about anything. Don't assume this game is going to be one way or another. Play it, all the way through the roughly 6 hour story, and take it for what it is: a personal game about choice.

Now, then. Always Sometimes Monsters is a story heavy RPG-esque game. It contains themes that are big in modern society, and manages to still handle them gracefully. Though I have played one run(and plan to do a few more), I feel what I have seen and played is a solid feel for what the game has to offer. This game is, in the weirdest sense, trying nbot to be a game, but more a narrative that takes place within the constraints of a video game. This litle tidbit is explored in a neat post-credits cutscene. I thoroughly enjoyed the 8 hours I've played so far, and I find that this was definitely a good investment. However, this is a review, so it should be lookedat from an objective standpoint. Please keep in mind, I have only done one full playthrough, so I can only vouch for certain aspects.

Characters: The characters are, to be frank, very fun. They have enjoyable lines which can make you laugh, cry, and possibly be very angry. I played as a standard white-bread hero, chasing a pretty white girl, so the story didn't incorporate race, sexuality, or gender into it, because it was a fairly standard setup in a video game. My character was, while a bit whiny, quite likeable. I wonder how much the actual lines spoken by your character change from person to person. The characters are flawed, but they don't have a hell of a lot of depth to them. You can really only take what you see on the surface, because we so rarely se the inner thoughts and emotions of these people. Other than that, I found the characters well-made, if a bit shallow.

Gameplay: You're going to pressing the spacebar a lot in this game. Gameplay usually stays on the standard path of learning about people, picking dialogue options, and sifting through menus. However, occasionally, the game deviates and has little set minigames(although games could hardly be used to describe them. They serve as very rudimentary tasks made to earn money to pay for food and bus tickets to other cities. They are, quite possibly, the biggest downfall of this game. They are boring. They're dull, repetitive, and they put you to sleep. They wouldn't be an issue were it not for the fact that they play an essential part in the game. You need money, and to get it, you have to do these jobs. It kills any pacing the story has, and just creates boring, mind-numbing situations for the player. I understand that the guys at Vagabond Dog were probably making them like this to make the point that Yep
recommended: but you've gotta do it." It doesn't make the task any less tedious
hoursPlayed: and the gameplay any less ♥♥♥♥ing monotonous.\n\nThe Story: This is the big part here

reviewText:
Very unique and interesting game. A lot of thought went into creating story and characters. Very deep development and many choices throughout the game.

Attempts to represents life in a very real way tackling prejudice, drugs and addiction, bigotry, homelessness, debt, hopelessness, corruption and love.

reviewText:
Always Sometimes Monsters isn't the most beautiful game. It's also not the most exciting game. However, it's packed with a lot of personality and if you're playing it right, you'll find yourself getting emotionally involved.

Many people were unhappy with the ending, but I felt that it represented the entire message of the game. We are always sometimes monsters.

I wouldn't pay the full $10 for this game, but it's definitely worth getting during a sale.

Coincidence, circumstance, choice, and consequence.

Unfortunately, if I were to give a letter grade to the overall game and my experience, I would have to be quite forgiving to remain using the letter 'C'.

A life simulator" if you will

hoursPlayed:
and along the road many scenarios and options are presented to tailor your experience in exactly how you will (or will not) achieve your goal.

The freedom of choice is apparent upon starting the game and persists throughout to an extent.  Sacrifice to help a friend or be selfish?  Take sides with party X or organization Y?  Take the high road or the low?  Many situations might give you pause to stop and consider your choices before committing.  Do you want to retain moral character or will the means justify the ends?  All of it is left to you as the player and will ultimately decide your fate.

In the end

reviewText:
Amazing game!

It's a very dramatic and emotional kind of game. The money I spent on getting this game was worth every dollar.
Almost Sometimes Monsters revolves around  you , or your character. You are faced with many choices that are obvious and hidden. The game touched some very sensitive issues which is really unique and sometimes confronting.

Almost Sometimes Monsters focus on the bad side, the flaws of the world, so don't expect the typical happily ever after or kiss in the sunset. When I played the game, I knew there were some really disturbing scenes, but I didn't think that it would make me really uncomfortable, whilst playing the game I felt that I grew closer to the characters, the situations, the consequences.

My favourite part of the game is not the tragedy, but the freedom and the many paths you could take. It's like playing a game made by Telltale Games mixed with Rockstar games. I played this game without getting any NPCs killed...I think...Actually there's this one jerk who really ticked me off, but I regretted it afterwards.

If you like RPGs, drama, violence, and tragedy then this is the game for you!

I can't wait for a new game (hopefully not disappointing) from you Vagabond Dogs! ♥

reviewText: Going into this game i was on the fence it had a lot of bad reviews and negative comments. I waiting till it was on sale and picked it up for 5$. What i got was a good suprise. IT took me roughly about 10 hrs to finish my frist playthrough and i will probably go for  another playthrough in the near future. I dont review games often but since all of the negativity this game is getting i thought i would put my opinion out there. I liked it alot and whish there was more like it out there. The decisions you make in this game are important and a lot of the time you will be stuck between a rock and a hard place and will have to make immoral decisions to make sure that you achive your goal, getting to San Verdano. This is a indie game and the writing is very witty and humourous at times but falls flat at others there are also a few typos here and there. This is a game about life and it may be a bit grindy at times but isnt normal life a grind going to a job from 9-5 on weekdays justo earn a living. This game is trying to simulate the same thing. To get to where you want you need to work hard while that nmay get boring in this game it is worth it to advance and go on your journey. There are multiple ending with the game but i was pretty happy with mine :) enjoy people this is a very underated gem.

If you really want to get invested and FEEL something play To the Moon"."

reviewText:
Ok so you want wondering if you should buy this game and you are looking in the steam user reviews and you happend to see my review and you see what i have to say. well what I have to say is this. This game is a great game for people who like a thick plot and choices that can change everything you know that is near and dear to your heart. if you don't...then just don't get this game. here are the pros to the game. The graphics are phenomenal the player and npc sprites are nice. the world is good and the top down perspective just makes it all work really well together. The dialog is really nice it makes you feel as if you are the character and you are talking to the npc.

Now the game play is pretty good. it plays like the over world in the old pokemon gameboy games were the character is in a overworld and he can go into biulding and interact witht he nc int he towns, or in this case a city.

Now come the cons. when you start the game it doesn't really tell you when you are selecting your character it just puts you in a room and you have to figure out what you have to do. for some people they will get this rigth away and have no problems, but for other they might be wondering what is going on. this is only minor thow because it will let you change your character if you are unplease by who you selected.

Sometime the game will delete you saved data and you will have to either start from a auto save or start from scratch. I only see this as a minor problem and will really only affect you if you are far in the game or just don't like doing thing more than once.

overall this is a good game and I would recommend this game to anyone who likes game where you are the one who is making the big decisions and doesn't mide reading for about five minutes. (that the longes I have read for one dialog)

reviewText: Cemented  in the struggles of everyday life, Always Sometimes Monsters focuses heavily on the morality, ethics and distance we are willing to travel for our desires. Although it suffers a little from linearity (choices against this essentially end with 'you did this, game ends here then'), there are many different paths and decisions you can choose to follow, and for that I highly recommend it.\n\nP.S. you'll regret selling ladybird :(
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I lit a camp fire for some old coot, it gave me the option to walk on it and I died horribly - 10/10


In all seriousness though I would give it closer to a 6/10, with only a soft-recommend due to some game design choices.

It's a hard game to point out my exact reason for the just slightly above average score without getting into spoilers. The story is really the reason to play this and how choice in it was handled at certain points (in terms of game design) are why I had to take points away.


Suffice it to say it was a geniunely interesting journey, that is designed in such a way to turn the decisions you made throughout the game into a meaningless illusion, all the while it sold itself on the idea that it was doing the opposite.

Anything that truly determines the final outcome happens within the last few moments and you're given full control in choosing them right then and there regardless of past actions.


That is a pretty major flaw for this sort of game in my opinion. It makes everything else you had given serious thought and consideration into choosing pretty much pointless.

You could theoretically experience all endings on a single playthrough if you save before these final choice moments, then reloading and playing the last 10-20min~ while choosing different combinations of options A or B" instead.

That's really not what the game makes itself out to be while you're going through it all
recommended: which is unfortunate since it would otherwise be the thought provoking work of art many people claim it to be."

reviewText: A well crafted and enjoyable RPG, Always Sometimes Monsters is a nice getaway from what many might conceive to be a bland market. It has quirks and charms that you don't find in many games, and the gameplay is well paced and not overwhelmingly long, leaving the player content at the end. Music and sound are good, dialogue tends to be pretty decent, and the storyline is almost believable - again, something reasonably rare for a game.\nOnly real fault I can find is that it may take a few hours of gameplay to pull you in, but I'd say it's worth it for the finished product. 7/10 for sure

My favorite part was when the aliens invaded in act 3.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Must play for:
- people who are sick with RPG Maker games in fantasy setting,
- people who thinks every RPG Maker game is bad.
Personally I don't care how game was made - if it's engine written from begin to end by devs or any version of RPG Maker, all of this is not important. What really matter is content and Always Sometimes Monsters doesn't fail in that matter. What is this game about? In short: it's about player, which means you. Every choice brings consequences. How the story will go and how will it end - it depend only on you and what you would do in some situations. It's not some kind of epic story, it's not also some masterpiece that will leave you speechless while playing or ending it - it's just a nice game full of things that might give you some thoughts, or not, and you will think it's trying to be something more than it is. There is a demo version of game, so give it a try and decide for yourself if you want to continue this story or not. I don't regret time spending playing Always Sometimes Monsters. In fact, I would gladly play more story-driven games.

reviewText: One of the most ambitious story driven adventures of recent times. Graphically simple but in many parts, well written. A series of hard choices (some, perhaps a little contrived) showing a quite startling reflection of yourself and how your choices affect others - refreshing in today's world of good vs evil game choice. Flawed in parts, but perhaps understandably given the amazing scope of this unique game, if you can look past its presentation you will have a memorable time with it

reviewText:
Have you ever promised something to someone and didn't follow thru?

Did you ever miss out on a concert to spend time with your boyfriend/girlfriend/wife/husband?

What were the consequences of your choices? That is what this game is trying to explain that we live far more complex lives than we think and it is changing the way we look at the medium of video games.  Its not about acheviments, high scores or saving the world.  This games makes the player realize that the choices we make have an impact on the people and world around us.  While its not a traditional game it is an experament that video games can be art and delve into the human condition.  If you are going into this game with doubts I'd say play it and it may or may not be for you but for me it made me realize that we can have major impacts on lives by making trivial decsions.  It's def something to think about.

reviewText:
I have very mixed feelings about this game, so let's go into it.

At first, it seemed to be a game about choices, with a deep, rich and ever-changing storyline, in which every little decision could change one's fate. But a quick internet search proves the opposite. Looking back, I can see that (virtually) every decision one makes in this game is about profiting money or not, and the choices made by the player change more about the NPCs lives than their own. I also could not yet understand how the very beginning of the game, the part with the mafioso guy, relates to everything else. In conclusion, the developers could have had put a lot more effort into the storyline, as it can be pretty deceiving, and the teaser video is also very misleading.

On the other hand, if one does not care very much about the storyline they can enjoy the game for a while. The pixel graphics and sprites are very well-made, but could have been better if the developers have used less colours and some dithering. The close-up of the characters are sometimes too anime-ish and ordinary and do not fit the game style. The soundtrack is the part which I have little or  nothing to complain about, and can act as a filler for the feelings that the story fails to deliver.

Talking about system requirements, this game needs a lot of disk space (320MB+) compared to it's graphics (here comes in the dithering and limited colour palettes I talked about, it could have reduced the image size A LOT). Sound could also have been better compressed, and the developers could have stuck to just one sound algorithm, instead of using both MP3 and OGG. This game is also very CPU and RAM demanding, and will probably not run in older or “weaker” machines. But I think that this all is because of RPG Maker. I also could not make the game fullscreen, as it would just lose the window borders and stay the same size. Doubling the window size makes the graphics lose quality due to interpolation. I also could not take screenshots with the Steam hotkey (F12) as the game would just crash or quit to the title screen. But I think these problems are caused by Wine.

Last thing is that Always Sometimes Monsters really lacks a tutorial or a key setup menu. The player isn't really supposed to know the controls beforehand and has to guess them.

After all, I feel that I cannot relate or empathize with this game's plot, and that's just because it is pretty shallow, linear and filled with “gratuitous violence” (like lots of people dying all the time). As the first game I bought on steam it was a very disappointing experience. I'll try to finish the game with at least one character, but I think this game is not really worth my time.

Long story short:

Graphics: 7/10 – Nice pixel graphics, but sometimes seeming out of place;
Soundtrack: 8/10 – The best part of this game is the soundtrack;
Story: 2/10 – Could have been much better if the developers had put a bit of effort into it;
System: 1/10 – Consumes way too much computing resources, there are better games out there which are less resource-hungry.

Overall: 4,5/10

P.S.: I apologize for any spelling error or weird sentences, as English is not my first language.

reviewText:
Surprisingly catchy!

I got this game out of a humble bundle, and I started playing it without ever looking at the store page. It is very confusing, because it is unlike most of the other games you can find on the market.

This is a game about life. Somewhat like The Sims, but this isn't about building a stable life, but rather about surviving a difficult life for a month, and try to get back the love of your life. Also much darker than the sims.

At first it will be boring and annoying, just like life. You need money to live, you need to work to get money, and nobody likes to work. But in the middle of these boring, work-filled days, you will be faced with several defining choices... And the next thing you know, you finished the game, and you feel like you just finished watching a really good movie or reading a really good book. And even though it is only a bunch of pixels, and not even particularly realistic, you will feel guilty for behaving like a real monster.

reviewText:
This is my first time writing a review on Steam and it's for a good reason.

Always Sometimes Monsters has to be the best game I've played in a long time. I was expecting a simple RPG that was a little cheesy but it far exceeded my expectations. The game is thought provoking and at some points dark and saddeninng but there's enough comic relief inbetween that kept me engaged. It's a really great balence.

The first time I played alway through it took me about 15 hours and I was heartbroken by my ending. Somehow I saw it coming but it still hurt. I felt like I deserved it based off of some of the decisions I made. It was odd. I then replayed it while reading a guide and I was a little happier with the ending but I was still saddened. There was no way to change the inevitable at the end. It made me think that in life maybe we are all Always Sometimes Monsters.

Yet in the end this game ruined my life. No other game I play compares now. All I can do is replay this game for some sense of satisfaction. The game developers for this game need to create another game soon because I need it. Or someone needs to point me in the direction of a  similar game because I'm craving more.

reviewText:
Always Sometimes Monsters...

If there's one constant in life: There's always sometimes monsters. It's engraved into our beings and soaked deeply into our souls; our primalistic desire to fight for love, and do anything to get it. ASM portrays this beautifully, and in many lights.

Down on your luck (and your money), you receive your final eviction notice. You're a broke author who never made it. How come?

Early on your hustle for money, you receive a wedding invitation...from your ex. What? But you haven't heard from them in a year, and now this?

So what do you do? You still love them, right? Of course! So now it's come down to this - 30 days to pick up the pieces of your life and get your ♥♥♥ back to them! But will you make it? Will you burn out on the way there? Will you die, lonely and destitute, as your life has become? Or will you make it, win your love back and maybe become the monster on the way?

What will you do for the chance at their heart again?

ASM is about forging your path back to the love of your life and more importantly, what you DID to get there. There are choices GALORE and many paths to follow. There's the distinct light / dark and all the in-betweens. Neat little minigames and collectibles and tons of engrossing dialogue. The music is also spot ON (big props to Laser Destroyer Team!) and definitely sets the mood for the scene at hand.

I count it as one of my absolute favorite games I've ever played, and not just because it was a great game, but because of the impact it made on me. It left me with chills and in tears and... complete fulfillment. Hell, even I as I type this, I'm shedding a few tears...

I simply can't recommend this game enough.

reviewText:
Always Sometimes Monsters: The game about you.

Unlike most rpgs where you're immersing yourself into the shoes of another person, Always Sometimes Monsters takes a different approach and asks you the question: What would YOU do?" and that is the game in a nutshell.

It asks you to be honest with yourself
date: to play through the story with the mindset that you are the pixilated sprite that's moving around the world.  Thus the game becomes more an exercise on self-discovery and seeing how high or low you would go if thrust into similar situations
recommended:
when you're backed into a corner would you really do what you did in game.

In the end the game is handicapped mechanically due to the limitations of the RPG Maker engine but solid writing throughout covers those shortcomings easily.  On occasion the writing can be a bit pretentious which adds a bit of disconnect seeing as the game is willing on to poke fun of the game and the developers themselves joke about in a cameo.

With branching avenues to take with every choice you make the game lends itself to multiple playthroughs which if you decide to play through all of them which could take you 15+ hours depending on if you skip through parts you've already seen.  Considering the price of the game if length is a factor in your purchases with its current price there's little reason not to pick it up if you're interested in a game about self discovery."

reviewText:
Looking back at the history of videogames I could risk to say that we have two fundamentally different types of game. These games can cover a variety of styles, but in essence they, on one side of the spectrum, ask from the player to take an active role, mechanically speaking, and on the other side of the spectrum, we have those that demand the user to be more emotionally involved being little demanding on aspects like hand/eye coordination. Of course the majority of videogames lie somewhere in-between these two extremes, but Always Sometimes Monsters (ASM) rests on the latter side, firmly.

ASM is just a simple RPG. You won't have deep character customization or a complex combat system. In fact there's no character customization, and combat, apart from a point where you might have to do some boxing, is non existent.

The game basically asks of you to eat and to get money for transport, just so that you can get to the end of your journey. But don'l let yourself be fouled, just like in our lives, what takes for a person to get such simple" tasks done can be a source of infinite complexity. Especially if you'r trying to do this balancing on the line of poverty and

reviewText: My girl left me, my publisher fired me, I'm broke, AND THE PROM IS TOMORROW!\n\nOn a more serious note, this is a great game that got me geniunely involved with the characters. Most games make you abundently clear that the characters are just that- characters. But in Always Sometimes monsters, I really felt like they were real people, with real consequences for my actions. This isn't a game for everyone, but for someone who likes adventures, a smidge of romance, and grey-and-grey moral choices that could end in disaster or in triumph, this is a shining example of what an RPG should look like. My only qualm was that it wasn't long enough.

reviewText:
If this game was solid through its entirety than I would recommend this purchase. Sadly, this game starts out strong only to leave you lacking and frustrated near the end.

With how compelling the first two thirds of this game were, I didn't think I'd find myself so annoyed and eager to finish and get this game out of the way. ASM already gives you tedious mini-games and tasks, but that's all the end game ended up being. I don't even need to explain the boxing minigame to those who have already played.

All in all this game had the potential to be something great, but for whatever reason took a sudden turn for the worse near the most climatic part of the game.

reviewText: This game is one of the most engaging and addicting I've played in a long time. The sense of choice and consequence, of defining who you are in the game world, of the unexpeccted chaos of life are all done exceedingly well up to par if not supperior to full counsel release rpgs. I'm 6 hours in and probably only half way but I'm still considering decisions made in the first hour. What storylines could have arisen from a different series of choices? Who could I have evolved into as a character would I be a better or worst person than I'm playing as now? If you love games with a slow paced but immersive story, roleplaying, and some heavy philisophical questions of how far you would go for love than this is a great game for you. Simple graphics and gamplay but as engaging as any mass effect or walking dead if you can really invest in the roleplay potential.
